so my journey to learning AWS believe it or not I only actually got
into technology in around 2009 I got a degree in accounting and finance and
basically I moved to the UK I had a graduate diploma in immigration law and actually worked
as an immigration lawyer for many years I had my own practice and I was teaching
people how to or showing people how to get visas to Australia to New Zealand to
Canada and into the UK and so I was very specialized in immigration law and then
the global financial crisis hit and in the UK the big problem was was all the
mortgages dried up so nobody could get mortgages either to buy new properties and nobody could sell their properties
to emigrate over - you know Australia New Zealand and Canada I'm so almost overnight our entire industry got wiped
out at the same time Australia New Zealand and Canada basically changed all the immigration
laws to make it harder for people to immigrate into those countries and so I was highly qualified but there was no
jobs so I decided to go into tech something I was always passionate about and it really did start from the bottom
so I went and got a job at a homeless charity so I was teaching the homeless how to use a you know how to log into
windows how to use email that sort of thing and I was also helping the staff out at that charity and during that time
I went to night school so I was doing my CCNA and my by my MCSE and it was quite
challenging I mean I was getting up at 7:30 every night and coming home at about 10 o'clock and you know it was
really tough time in my life but it was really really worth it in the end and so for the back of those two qualifications
I got a job at Rackspace in 2010 and originally I was a Windows system administrator but I moved into a
solutions architecture role and it was great I really enjoyed it Rackspace I was in the SMB team so I was really
dealing with like two or four server solutions and it got pretty boring pretty quickly I mean two web servers
two deep database servers that's it next customer please and so I wanted to move on to larger solutions so I moved over
to a company called Phoenix which big in the UK but they're they're not so well they're only in the UK and that was
working with about 20 service solutions and then after a year I moved over the Sun guard and some guard availability
systems and that was much bigger solutions we're talking about normally about 200 servers we'd have multiple
data centers all around country and it wasn't just network infrastructure like we had to do the you know comms line so
we had to do MPLS circuits we had to do dedicated coms but it was also workplace
recovery so like if an insurance company has a fire what happens with their corporate officers how do you move
everyone to like a Regis office for example and then how do you do all the networking behind there I was really
fascinating because you're solving a whole bunch of complex problems but the problem was it was all on dedicated
infrastructure and I started watching what's happening the AWS space and things like CloudFormation was coming
out or elastic beanstalk and I started thinking oh my god dedicated infrastructures is starting to become
code it's you know there's a massive transformation and if I don't start learning in staying ahead of the curve
I'm gonna end up just like what I was you know where I was in an immigration industry and suddenly the entire you
know industry collapses overnight and so I became really focused on learning AWS but I was on a very tight budget we
didn't have any kind of training budget available to us so I had to go out and learn this stuff myself and so and I
figured out to do there was only four certifications at that time but for me to go out and do that if I was going to
do it like in you know in classroom it's going to cost me about nine thousand pounds which is the equivalent to you
know one year's tuition at university so in comes you to me I've always been
using you to be to learn things about tech it's great platform the problem is with udemy is that it's
not just about tech it will teach you programming and stuff but they also have courses on like photography or you know
my little pony believe it or not so it was quite interesting and I did a whole
bunch of AWS courses on udemy but I wasn't pleased with those courses so I decided to create my own as a part of me
learning AWS and so I am in December of 2014 I created a certified Solutions
Architect associate course and I was basically preparing the course while studying so it was a way of helping me
to study to pass that certification and I launched that course on the 9th of January in 2015 I actually launched it
an hour before I set the actual exam which not a lot of people know about and I actually with my mobile phone I do
turn it into flight mode I just turned it into silent and I put my mobile phone in a locker and which was behind me
while I was doing the court doing the exam and I had just before I launched the course to give away two hundred free
copies to that course on reddit and every time somebody signed up to it I'd get an email and I could hear my phone
while I was doing the exam just going and it was driving me absolutely crazy
but I managed to pass the exam I was really ecstatic and so I decided to start charging money for the course
after those two hundred copies you know had been given away and and then that's when a cloud guru was basically born and
started going viral fast-forward a little bit I did the developer associate and the systems
administrator associate courses I registered a company in May 20th of May
last year and then my brother I said to my brother in about August that this was
really starting to take off and would he be interested in helping me build out a platform we looked at using Moodle we
looked at using Joomla a whole bunch of others but nothing really met our needs
so Sam as comes from a software engineering background I had worked at Microsoft before he decided just to

launched on the 1st of September and last year and we build it in a server less of you know completely server
lessly so we run in angularjs across all devices in the front end you're

our LMS and we use cloud search we use author 0 for authentication all our
